Type Parameters:

All Implemented Interfaces:
ReversibleIterator<T>, UniversalIterator<T>, Iterable<T>, Enumeration<T>, Iterator<T>
Direct Known Subclasses:
ArrayIterator, CharacterIterator, JListIterator, MatchResultIterator, NodeListIterator
public abstract class ListIterator<T>
extends AbstractReversibleIterator<T>

Abstract, template method-based iterator over a list or list-like structure.

Subclasses need only define the starting and ending positions in the list, as well as the mechanism for accessing the element at a given position.

In general, there is no defense mechanism preventing modification of any underlying list while this iterator is in use. Any changes will therefore propagate through to users of this iterator. Taking advantage of this is discouraged.

Constructor Detail

ListIterator

protected ListIterator(int begin,
                       int end,
                       boolean reverse)
Constructs an iterator that will traverse the list values in the specified range of positions, possibly in reverse order. The first position is inclusive, the last position is not inclusive. This constructor makes it straightforward for subclasses to implement the ReversibleIterator.reverse() method, as in this example: 
 public class ExampleListIterator<T> extends ListIterator<T> {
        private final ExampleList<T> list;
 
        public ExampleListIterator(ExampleList<T> list) {
                this(list, false);
        }
 
        protected ExampleListIterator(ExampleList<T> list, boolean reverse) {
                super(list.begin(), list.end(), reverse);
                this.list = list;
        }
 
        public ReversibleIterator<T> reverse() {
                return new ExampleListIterator<T>(list, true);
        }
 }

Parameters:
begin - the first position in the range
end - the position immediately after the last position in the range
reverse - whether or not to reverse the traversal order
